Dataset content: This is a dataset derived from analysis to produce estimates of the number of households living in fuel poverty in England. Previously, a household was defined as being fuel poor if they spent more than 10% of their income on fuel. The data cover modelled household fuel costs and consumption. It is based on the English Housing Survey which interviews c. 13,300 households and inspects c. 6,200 dwellings.
Geography notes: Freely available datasets have restricted geographic identifiers to avoid disclosure of participants.  English Housing Survey datasets with detailed geographic identifiers may appear to be available via Secure Access agreement with the UK Data Service although it is not clear what level of geographical identifier could be obtained. Scottish and NI equivalent surveys exist but fuel poverty definitions vary.
Time notes: The survey operates continuously. Data for the household survey are analysed annually and for the physical survey on a two-year rolling basis. Prior to 2008, the constituent elements of the English Housing Survey were run as separate surveys. Fuel poverty datasets were produced by DECC from 2003 onwards.
Data type notes: This is a derived dataset created on the basis of the English Housing Survey Sample Survey. Levels of potential sampling error within this survey are assessed. Greater detail on this can be found in the Technical Report
Data quality:
- The sample for the survey is representative of England. There was a transition in methodology from 2011 to 2012 from a simple random sample to a partially clustered survey design for a single survey year. The survey is stratified by geog region, tenure, and household with an HRP who worked in a non-manual occupation (2001 census) and subsampled by tenure.  
- The sample for the survey is drawn from the Postcode Address File (PAF) obtained from the Post Office. This offers a good coverage of residential households and dwellings in England. The sample does not however include any new dwellings built after the PAF was collated. The weights are adjusted using the number of new dwellings built between the PAF date and the reference date for the weighting to account for this error in coverage.
- Standardised training is in place to minimise measurement error both amongst interviewers and surveyors
- For the interview section, full-scale piloting of new questions is not carried out but new questions are reviewed following the first quarter of data collection
- The greatest variability in subjectivity in the physical survey is likely to revolve around the assessment of housing condition and defects. However, a surveyor variation study was carried out in 2009/10 which showed no significant difference in surveyor assessments 
- Non-response bias is dealt with in the weighting process
- Greater detail on measures undertaken to enhance data quality are provided in a Technical Report
Data access: Anonymised English Housing Survey data sets are released each year once the main annual reports have been published, via End User Licences available to all members of the public at the UK Data Service.  Registration for this service is slightly different for HE/FE users. The English Housing Survey datasets with detailed geographic identifiers are available only via Secure Access at the UK Data Service
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.
Other notes: The government is looking to reduce the cost of the English Housing Survey. Following a review in early 2015, they have decided to not pause the survey or continue it on a biannual basis. However, it is likely that aspects of the survey methodology and the data collected will alter somewhat in the upcoming years.

Category notes: Subsidy and benefit, Property and Physical Characteristics-land may also apply to this dataset
Dataset content: This data comes from a periodic follow-up survey of private landlords and agents (the Private Landlords Survey (PLS)) is conducted using information from the English Housing Survey interview survey. Information collected includes: respondent characteristics; landlord's portfolio; nationality/ethnicity; licensing; letting practice; acquisition of the rental property; current letting; financial information about current letting; tenancies that ended in last two years; repairs; neighbourhood; landlord problems.
Geography notes: Freely available datasets have restricted geographic identifiers to avoid disclosure of participants.  English Housing Survey datasets with detailed geographic identifiers may appear to be available via Secure Access agreement with the UK Data Service although it is not clear what level of geographical identifier could be obtained.
Time notes: This follow-up survey is conducted periodically. It was conducted in 2001, 2003, 2006 and 2010
Data type notes: As with previous years, the 2010 survey was based on information collated on DCLG's main housing survey. Respondents taking part in the ECHS 2007-2008 (see under SN 6449 on UK Data Service site) and the EHS 2008-2009 (see under SN 7040 on UK Data Service site) who were recorded as private renters were asked to provide details of their landlord. These details formed the main sample for the 2010 PLS.
Data quality: Some changes were made to questions between the 2006 and 2010 versions of the questionnaire which presents issues for continuity. New questions were included which look at choice of letting/management agent for instance. The sample was derived from renters' responses to two years' of the household interviews. Landlords whose properties were empty at the time of the initial survey are therefore excluded. Where tenants refused to participants, landlords were also excluded. As a sampling frame for private landlords the PLS therefore suffers from under-coverage. "problem landlords" and "problem tenants" may also be underrepresented due to non-response bias.
Data access: An anonymised PLS dataset is provided for 2010 via the UK Data Service. Datasets with additional geographic identifiers are available only via Secure Access at the UK Data Service although the unit of this is not clear. It seems likely that datasets for 2001, 2003 and 2006 could be obtained although these would need to be requested,
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.
Other notes: The government is looking to reduce the cost of the English Housing Survey. Following a review in early 2015, they have decided to not pause the survey or continue it on a biannual basis. However, it is likely that aspects of the survey methodology and the data collected will alter somewhat in the upcoming years. It is not clear if they plan to conduct the Private Landlords Survey again.

Category notes: Expenditure
Dataset content:
4,761 households in GB co-operated fully in the survey in 2013.  The response rate in GB in 2013 was 48%, a decrease from 52% in 2012.  The response rate for NI was 61% in 2013, a decrease from 67% in 2012.  
Individuals keep diary records of daily expenditure for two weeks. Children aged 7-15 asked to keep simplified diaries. Main results from the survey are published by ONS in the annual report Family Spending.

From April 2001 to 2008, these survey were combined to form the Expenditure and Food Survey. Living Cost and Food Survey replaced the Expenditure and Food Survey in 2008.
Data type notes:
LCF sample for Great Britain is a multi-stage stratified random sample with clustering. It is drawn from the Small Users file of the Postcode Address File (PAF) ? the Post Office?s list
of addresses.

Category notes: The SCORE dataset records property type and condition, rent and affordability measures in addition to demographic information about tenants.
Dataset content: SCORE collects information from Registered Social Landlords (RSLs) about the new lets that they make in any given year. Information includes: demographic information or tenant households;  their pathway to becoming a tenant; the financial profile of tenant households; the type and condition of the property being let; and the financial aspects of the let being made, including rent and affordability. It contains c. 20000 new lets each year
Geography notes: SCORE collects data at the individual RSL level, however, annual reports and the data tables released with them are aggregated to at least the local authority level. Some measures are given for Scotland as a whole.
Time notes: SCORE was discontinued in Mar 2015
Data type notes: SCORE is a voluntary survey of all RSLs requesting information on characteristics of all their new lets
Data quality:
- According to the Scottish Government, SCORE has only approx.78% coverage of new RSL lets due to its voluntary status. It is suggested that there are ?particular gaps in Glasgow RSLs, meaning that overall results are not fully representative of the sector?.
- It is noted that many responses to the survey are incomplete and, in some instances, the effective response rate has dropped as low as 35%, potentially creating bias. 
- The robustness of results, particularly those related to household income, has been questioned due to the basic recording of this data within RSLs and limited triangulation. 
- It only contains data relating to new lets so it cannot be assumed to be a valid proxy for the whole RSL sector. Furthermore, RSLs represent less than half of the social rented sector and, as no comparable data is available for LA new lets, no understanding of its representativeness for the whole sector can be gleaned.
Data access: Some data tables are published with the annual reports and are thus freely available through the Scottish Government website. Additional data would also be available through application and agreement with government. The smallest scale of data that could be obtained is not clear.
Data owner attitude to research use: The website suggests a favourable attitude  to access for research purposes. The access request form does, however, require clarity regarding any data linkage that researchers are looking to carry out.

Dataset name: Families in bed and breakfast accommodation for more than 6 weeks

Under the Homelessness Act 2002, local housing authorities must have a strategy for preventing homelessness in their district. The strategy must apply to everyone at risk of homelessness, including cases where someone is found to be homeless but not in priority need and cases where someone is found to be intentionally homeless.
Time notes: In April 2008, the quarterly P1E form (which collects data on local authorities? actions under homelessness legislation) was expanded to include a new section on the homelessness prevention and relief taking place outside the statutory framework.Homelessness prevention and relief publications from 2008 are available via the national archive.

Data quality:
Data are reported via the quarterly P1E forms All P1E returns submitted  undergo thorough validation and cross-checking and late returns are pursued to ensure overall response is as complete and accurate as possible. Anomalous data are highlighted and verified by contacting the
local authority.The overall response rate for 2014/15 was 96.9%

Dataset name: Homelessness Reference Tables/Housing Options (PREVENT1) Statistics in Scotland
Dataset content: The dataset provides information on the monitoring of the impact of housing options work, collected from the PREVENT1 return. This relates to  homelessness prevention approaches to local authorities and outcomes. It includes demographic data on applicants and vulnerabilities. Data is also provided on the number of prevention approaches which translate into homelessness applications
Time notes: Data are published on a financial year basis e.g. 2014-15. Statistics are produced bi-annually (i.e. 2014-15 & six-montly update). They are however considering moving the PREVENT1 statistical release to an annual format from summer 2016
Data type notes: These data are drawn from the PREVENT1 case level data collection to monitor housing options/ homelessness prevention in Scotland. One month after the end of each quarter, local authorities are asked to submit an XML file containing the information as set out in the data specification
Data quality: These data are government administrative data.
Data access: A freely accessible data table is provided via the Scottish Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: IT providers have been asked to implement the data specification as fully as possible in order to enhance the quality of the data. Local authorities may re-submit data to fix these errors or they can comment them to explain why they believe the data to be valid.  On submission of the data to the Scottish Government, each local authority is sent a detailed automatic report showing the contents of the data and any remaining errors. Specific data quality issues relating to individual councils are highlighted in the report which accompanies the dataset release, which contains a section on Data Quality.

Dataset name: Homelessness Reference Tables/Operation of the Homeless Persons Legislation in Scotland
Dataset content:
This statistics bulletin provides information on homelessness applications, assessments and outcomes. It includes information on the
characteristics of applicant households, local authority assessments and the action taken in respect of cases that were concluded. Snapshot data on households in temporary accommodation are also presented, together with data on the implementation of the Homeless Persons (Unsuitable Accommodation) (Scotland) Order 2014
Time notes: These statistics are provided as quarterly updates but no quarterly figures are released for Jan-Mar when annual figures are released. Figures for households in temporary accommodation used to be released as a separate dataset. These were incorporated into this data release in 2006. Separate datasets for households in temporary accommodation are available from 2002. They are considering altering the frequency of this release to either biannual or annual in order to free up resources.
Data type notes: These data are administrative data collected on HL1 and HL2 returns
Data quality: As local authority administrative data, it provides coverage of all 32 local authorities in Scotland. Some data quality issues are highlighted. Given the continuous nature of the recording system, figures are updated on an on-going basis and may differ from those previously published. Additional points of note, relating to, for instance, changes in data collection are detailed in a 'General notes and missing data' section' in the report accompanying the statistical release.
Data access: Freely accessible datasets are provided via the Scottish Government website. For the most part these relate to individual years however time series datasets are provided for 1989/90-1999/00. Households in temporary accommodation data is available in from 2002
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Dataset content: This dataset contains count & estimate information for the number of people rough sleeping in a local authority. These counts and estimates are single-night snap shots.
Time notes: These statistics were published under new guidance from 2010. Figures that were collected and published previous to this new guidance are available in the Rough Sleeping England - Total Street Count and Estimates 2010 and the Rough Sleeping England - Total street count 2009 tables. These tables include previous data back to 1998.
Data type notes: Rough sleeping counts and estimates are single night snapshots of the number of people sleeping rough in local authority areas. Local authorities decide whether to carry out a count or an estimate based upon their assessment of whether the local rough sleeping problem justifies counting. They are encouraged to gain intelligence for street counts and estimates from local agencies such as outreach workers, the police, the voluntary sector and members of the public who have contact with rough sleepers on the street.
Data quality: Some figures within the dataset are estimated rather than based on counts. Counts are single night snapshots of the number of people sleeping rough. Although accurately counting or estimating the number of rough sleepers within the area of a local  authority is inherently difficult, the series is now regarded as well-established, with a consistent run of figures over five years, and with their robustness enhanced by Homeless Link being involved in verifying local counts and validating local estimates
Data access: A freely accessible data table is provided as part of the release
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable

The Survey of English Housing (centred on housing circumstances and attitudes) collected information from c.20,000 households and operated continuously from 1993/4 to 2007/8. Fire and Fire sfety data was only separated out into a stand alone section of the English Housing Survey in 2012
Data type notes: Levels of potential sampling error are assessed for this survey. Greater detail on this can be found in the Technical Report
Data quality:
- The sample for the survey is representative of England. There was a transition in methodology from 2011 to 2012 from a simple random sample to a partially clustered survey design for a single survey year. The survey is stratified by geog region, tenure, and household with an HRP who worked in a non-manual occupation (2001 census) and subsampled by tenure.  
- The sample for the survey is drawn from the Postcode Address File (PAF) obtained from the Post Office. This offers a good coverage of residential households and dwellings in England. The sample does not however include any new dwellings built after the PAF was collated. The weights are adjusted using the number of new dwellings built between the PAF date and the reference date for the weighting to account for this error in coverage.
- Standardised training is in place to minimise measurement error  amongst interviewers 
- Full-scale piloting of new questions is not carried out but new questions are reviewed following the first quarter of data collection
- Non-response bias is dealt with in the weighting process
- Greater detail on measures undertaken to enhance data quality are provided in a Technical Report

Dataset name: Scottish Household Survey (including Scottish House Condition Survey)
Category notes: Also, demographics, property (physical characteristics), accessibility, social characteristics
Dataset content: The survey is a continuous survey based on on a sample of the general population in private residences in Scotland. It provides household and individual information on the characteristics, attitudes and behaviour of Scottish households and individuals. The data are very wide-ranging. A copy of the questionnaire utilised in the survey is provided on the Scottish Government website.
Geography notes: The survey is only designed to be representative at the local authority level on a two-year basis. Follow up surveys and Special Datasets, which may be available at the individual level, may be available where approval is obtained.
Time notes:
Data for the SHS are recorded continuously but annual reports with associated web tables are published annually. 

The survey started in 1999 and up to 2011 followed a fairly consistent survey design.  From 2012 onwards, the survey was substantially redesigned to include elements of the Scottish House Condition Survey (SHCS) including the follow-up Physical Survey component.

Data for the Scottish House Condition Survey is available from 2003
Data type notes: Organised in two-year cycles, it interviews around 14,500 households per annum and can provide data disaggregated at local authority level at the end of each cycle.  The survey is conducted as a two-part interview.  The first is the ?Household? element, asked of a householder (typically the Highest Income Householder) or their spouse/partner.  The second is an ?Adult? element, asked of a random adult within the household.
Data quality: Annual Technical reports are provided alongside annual reports to detail the methodology and data quality issues of the SHS. As a sample survey, the EHS suffers from sample error and some coverage issues. Although there are no geographical exclusions to the survey, the sampling frame does not cover the whole population because of a combination of inherent limitations and administrative errors and delays. Some variables are subjective and aspects such as reported income may be reported erroneously. There are also some issues with continuity in the data due to a substantial redesign in 2012. For more details on limitations of the data please see published technical reports.
Data access: Annual publications are produced with web tables which are freely accessible. For datasets including an local authority identifier, data request forms must be completed. A dataset called SHS Lite is available to encourage use of the Scottish Household Survey. This must be requested and is provided on a CD. Web pages highlight that additional datasets can be requested.
Data owner attitude to research use: Although data are not freely released, SHS lite is produced to encourage non-commercial uses of the data. Extensive details are also provided on webpages detailing the process and forms needed for accessing data for research use.

Data type notes: This is administrative data from local authority systems, recorded on the quarterly NB1 and NB2 statistical returns for council and private house building completions, stock 4 returns record changes in housing stock and in stock tenure, and also information from the Affordable Housing Supply Programme (AHSP) (formally Affordable Housing Investment Programme (AHIP)) on housing association new build and refurbishment. It records all new build housing, refurbishments and conversions for housing use.  NB2 returns collecting private house building is collected a quarter behind the local authority NB1 return
Data quality: These are government administrative data and are thus high quality. These statistics offer complete coverage of the 32 local authorities in Scotland and there is therefore no sampling error associate with these statistics. A document detailing quality issues for HSfS statistics is provided alongside releases.
Data access: A full freely accessible data table is provided via the Scottish Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Social and academic research is an acknowledged use of these statistics according to the 'Use of the data' documentation provided alongside the HSfS releases

Dataset name: Public Authority Housing Stock (Housing Statistics for Scotland)
Dataset content:
time series tables of stock owned by local authorities and Scottish Homes, by:

- type of property (house, high rise flat, tenement flat, 4 in a block, other flat/maisonette)
- year of construction (pre-1919, 1919-1944, 1945-1964, 1965-1982, post-1982)
- construction type (traditional, non-traditional)
- normal use of stock (normal letting stock, temporary accommodation for the homeless, other)
Data quality: These are administrative data and therefore offer complete coverage of the 32 local authorities of Scotland. As government data, they can be considered high quality. Nevertheless, a Data Quality report is provided with alongside all HSfS statistical releases
Data access: A full freely accessible data table is provided via the Scottish Government website which gives time series data at the local authority level for 1998-2015
Data owner attitude to research use: Social and academic research is an acknowledged use of these statistics according to the 'Use of the data' documentation provided alongside the HSfS releases

Dataset content:
The Scottish Housing Quality Standard (SHQS) is a measure of the quality of the housing stock. It is an aggregation of the results from 49 different programme modules aggregated into 5 higher-level categories which in turn provide a single pass/fail classification for all dwellings.

The 5 higher level classifications are: below the tolerable standard; energy efficient; modern facilities and services; healthy, safe and secure; and free from serious disrepair. This indicator shows the Number of dwelings that fail the Scottish Housing Quality Standard in Scotland.
Data type notes: Count and Ratio
Data quality: Technical information available from the Scottish Government webpage
Data access: Years 2004-2011 available freely on the Scottish Government Statistics website.  PDF Progress reports available from the Scottish Housing Regulator website for the years 2007/08-2012/13
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable

Dataset content: This dataset contains information on Service Family Accommodation in the UK, including numbers of dwellings by country and by surveyed condition.
Time notes: Data releases are provided for 2013,2014 and 2015. However, data are presented in time series and therefore cover 2007-2013, 2008-2014 and 2008-2015.
Data type notes: These data drawn on MOD administrative data
Data quality: The data in these tables have been extracted from a MOD database which is considered to be reliable and there are no significant concerns over the accuracy of data. In addition to validation by DIO, the data in these tables have been subjected to a sense check by Government statistician. A Background Quality Report is also provided with each statistical release
Data access: Freely available datasets are provided for 2013,2014 and 2015 which cover 2007-2013, 2008-2014 and 2008-2015 respectively.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Category notes: attittudes/preferences/social characteristics (place)
Dataset content:
40,000 households interviewed in 1997
12,000 dwellings were inspected in 1998
Time notes: Previous Housing Condition Surveys were carried out in Wales during 1968, 1986 and 1993.  The Housing Condition Survey was replaced by the Living in Wales Survey.
Data type notes: Numeric and textual data
Data access: Free to download as a PDF report from the Scottish Government Website
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Dataset content: Data collected from local authorities and RSLs. Compliance with the WQHS amongst providers including local authorities and RSLs.
Data type notes: Numeric
Data quality: Technical report detailing data quality issues available on the Welsh Government website link.
Data access: Free to download as an excel spreadsheet/PDF report from Welsh Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research.

Dataset content: Reporting by Local Planning Authorities and RSLs as well as other community and voluntary providers, as to the number of affordable housing units delivered. Number of affordable housing units delivered in Wales. Financial contribution via planning agreement by local authority. Additional affordable units provided by RSLs only, tenure and funding. Additional affordable units by provider type, tenure, location, year and funding.
Data type notes: Numeric
Data quality: Technical report on data quality available from the Welsh Government website link.
Data access: Data free to download from the Welsh Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears favourable to the use of data for research.

Dataset name: Houses in Multiple Occupation (Housing Statistics for Scotland)
Dataset content: This dataset contains information on Housing in Multiple Occupation licences. Data included are: new and renewal applications received, applications granted and licences in force; all applications received and type of HMO; all applications under the mandatory licensing scheme and licenses in force and a Scotland-level summary of applications under the mandatory licensing scheme and licenses in force
Time notes: A time-series dataset is provided which gives information for 2001-2015
Data type notes: Data are drawn from local authority administrative records.
Data quality: The dataset has a full coverage of all 32 local authorities in Scotland. The Data Quality report, produced alongside the HSfS statistical releases, highlights some data quality issues. It is noted that information on HMOs is generally believed to be of good quality. However, the returns received from some local authorities are inconsistent from one year to the next suggesting that these LAs have difficulties in tracking applications made in one financial year where the decision on that application is made in the next financial year.
Data access: A full freely accessible data table is provided via the Scottish Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Social and academic research is an acknowledged use of these statistics according to the 'Use of the data' documentation provided alongside the HSfS releases

Category notes: Also cost, price, rent
Dataset content: Commercial rental data has been combined with NIHE rent data.  The NIHE rental data is used to calculate the Local Housing Allowance received for the administration of private sector housing benefit.  In order to combine the data sets, the NIHE rent data has been adjusted to the preferred monthly frequency and adjusted upward by property type to be inclusive of (domestic) rates. Sample survey of data (for example, the report for January - June 2015 was based on a sample of 11,443 rental transactions for the first half of 2015).
Time notes:
Bi-annually

Figures for the private rented sector in the Belfast Metropolitan area are available from 2009.
Data quality: Data has been cleansed to remove outlier.  Further methodological information available from NIHE website.
Data access: Free to download from the NIHE website
Data owner attitude to research use: Seems favourable to data use for research.  The development of the research has been done in conjunction with the University of Ulster.

Dataset content: Annual returns from Welsh social landlords (local authorities and RSLs). Records of social housing sales (local authority and RSL dwellings)
Time notes: Data for right to buy from 1980-81 until 2012-13 inclusive. Up until 2010-11 the data was collected on a quarterly basis, and from 2011-12 collected annually. The figures for each financial year represent the sales during each of the financial years from April to March.
Data type notes: Numeric
Data quality: Technical report available on the Welsh Government website
Data access: Data free to download on the Welsh Government website as PDF report and Excel spreadsheet.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Dataset content:
APAT LGA uses Land Registry (LR) data from 1995 for each region, county, unitary district and London borough in England & Wales, and Registers of Scotland (RoS) data from 2003 for each local authority in Scotland. Sales volumes and average transacted by property type. Provides the average price for each property type in each LGA (but only if three properties of the same type have been sold in the month being reported).
Some adjustments due to LGA boundary changes
Geography notes: Also includes Scotland (but not Northern Ireland)
Data quality: Data is checked, smoothed, updated and time adjusted.
Data access: Not freely Accessible, costs unknown.  A free sample of APAT LGA (2008/09) is available to download

Dataset content:
Index based on the Halifax' own data for house purchase transactions which are financed via mortgage approval. Information is obtained about: purchase price, location (region)
type of property, Age of property, tenure and number of rooms, separate toliets, central heating, number of garages/garage spaces, garden, land area of greater than one acre, road charge liability. From this, a number of standardised indices are generated covering different categories of houses and of buyers (first time buyers and former owner-occupiers), 
The database is described as 'exceptionally large'
Geography notes: Government Office regions and includes Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales
Time notes: Longest running monthly house price series
Data quality: Only covers mortgages therefore does not include cash purhases.  The Halifax only uses its own data because it can process it immediately and does not need to await the receipt of data from other lenders which means that they are more timely than the ONS HPI
Data access: Data free to download from the Halifax website as an excel spreadsheet including historical data from 1983.
Data owner attitude to research use: No view appears expressed on use of the data for academic research

Dataset content:
Data is based on a sub-sample of the Regulated Mortgage Survey (RMS). The HPI is calculated using mortgage completions data that is collected via the regulated mortgage survey - undertaken by the Council of Mortgage Lenders. This covers the majority of mortgage lenders in the UK. The size of the sample depends on the number of mortgage completions in the month of interest.  Across the months of 2012, the average sample size was 27,000; typically, summer months are more active than winter months.  Data includes information on distribution and ratios of houseprices including by type of buyer, new/other dwellings. income of borrowers and deposit.
Tables under the House Price Indices heading include:
House Price Index, tables 1-19 - 1-9 updated each month, 10-19 updated quarterly (February, May, August, and November)
House Price Index, tables 20-39 - updated annually (either March or July)
Index of Private Housing Rental Prices, Reference Tables (Quarterly)
House Price Statistics for Small Areas, local authorities, parliamentary constituencies and middle layer super output areas, Englad and Wales, 1995-2014
Geography notes: Government Office Regions including Northern Ireland, Wales and Scotland
Time notes: Data previously found on DCLG 'live tables' and the ONS HPI replaces the DCLG monthly HPI since April 2012.  The Regulated Mortgage Survey which provides the source of the ONS HPI has been conducted since 1969, see CML for further information.
Data type notes: Although the survey data covers all mortgage lenders, lenders covering 75-80% of the mortgage market submit data used to calculate the HPI.  Only mortgage transactions for owners occupiers are included, cash purchases are not included in the CML dataset. Buy to let properites and remortgages are also excluded.Data based on actual transactions.
Data quality: Changes in sample size: Since its conception, the index relies on the use of mortgage transaction data but excludes cash sales.  Originally when it began in 1969, the index was calculated from a 5% sample of the mortgage transactions of a number of buildings societies.  From 1993, the coverage of transactions increased to cover all mortgage lenders. In 2003, the sample submitted by each mortgage lender expanded from 5% to cover all their recorded mortgage transactions.  A full breakdown of the ONS HPI methodology is available here: http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/hpi/house-price-index-guidance/official-house-price-statistics-explained/index.html
Data access: Data easily accessible and available to download from ONS
Other notes: Data previously found on DCLG 'live tables' and the ONS HPI replaces the DCLG monthly HPI since April 2012

Dataset content: Subscription service. Precise blend of datasets used is unknown but website claims that more than 250 are used including Land Registry and Mortgage valuation data supplied by lenders. Online data analysis tool designed for local authorities and housing associations. Includes information on prices over time, affordability, prices per property type, per square metre, demand for affordable housing, structure of the local rental market. Concerns have been expressed about reliability for Scotland and NI but these have not been verified.
Geography notes: Area profiles available down to 150 households
Time notes: This is an on-demand housing analysis tool
Data quality:
No data available although Whitehead et al (2009) provide some insights into the potential weaknesses of Hometrack data.

Whitehead,  C, Monk, S, Clarke, A, Holman, A, Markkanen, S (2008) Measuring Housing  Affordability: A Review of Data Sources (National Housing and Planning Advice  Unit)       - See more at: http://www.landecon.cam.ac.uk/directory/anna-clarke#sthash.bpCDgHtx.dpuf
Data access: Hometrack is a private data provider and their data analysis tool is only available via annual subscription.  Ad hoc data is available, priced to customers' requirements.

Dataset content: Residential property transactions.  Based on repeat sales regression, which calculates 'change' in house prices since 1995 therefore new build properties are excluded
Geography notes: No equivalents seem to exist for Scotland or NI.
Time notes: Normally published on the 20th working day of the month
Data quality: High quality as records all financial transactions on residential property but excludes new build
Data access: Freely accessible via a web based reporting function - allowing comparison between different areas and downloadable as Excel/turtle syntax file/SPARQL query

Dataset content: The Local authority housing bulletin collates a range of time series statistics on volume of transactions and house prices.
Time notes: The Local Authority Housing Bulletin was published monthly until September 2014. It was published for the last time in September 2015
Data type notes: The majority of figures are drawn from Local authority administrative data. Additional data utilised in the publication are drawn from the Registers of Scotland and Nationwide
Data quality: Data quality issues will vary amongst data sources. Data drawn from local authority administrative systems and the Registers of Scotland can be considered high quality. The publication offers full coverage of the local authorities of Scotland.
Data access: PDFs of all publications 2011-2015 are freely available via the Scottish Government website. Statistical datasets are not however provided alongside the releases. It is not clear if these could be obtained by request.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Dataset content: Index seeks to provide a 'true measure' of house price inflation.
Geography notes: Government office regions of England and Wales although a Scottish HPI is also available on the Acadata's website.
Data quality: ONS suggest that this is 'the only house price index to reflect all transactions, as opposed to data samples, and provides mix and seasonally adjusted results at national, regional and county or unitary district or London borough levels'
Data access: Freely available to download from the Acadata website as Excel spreadsheet although source must be acknowledged.
Data owner attitude to research use: Unknown but data is provided through a commercial data consultancy but which is making use of publicly available information from the land registry

Category notes:
Monthly volume of sales
Monthly average residential prices
Dataset content: Covers all sales of residential properties registered with Registers of Scotland (RoS) in the quarter where the selling price of the property lies between 20,000 and 1,000,000. Size of dataset will vary according to how many sales take place during the month.
Time notes: A quarterly time series is also available.
Data type notes: Monthly Statistics time series which is also used to generate quarterly housing statistics and a ten year report detailing house price trends in Scotland.
Data access: Free to download as an Excel spreadsheet from Registers of Scotland website.

Dataset content: Index based on the Nationwide's own data for house purchase transactions which are financed via mortgage approval.  Approvals data is used as opposed to mortgage completions since it provides an earlier indication of current trends. Nationwide prices are mix adjusted - track a representative house price over time rather than the average price. An exact sample size is not provided but Nationwide state that they have sufficient data to produce a representative house price series as they are the second largest mortgage lender in the UK with an average market share of 15% (2012-2015). Regional coverage likely to be uneven (e.g. not so strong in Scotland).
Time notes: The Nationwide have been producing a house price index since 1952 although this was published on a quarterly basis until 1991 when it became monthly.
Data quality:
Re-mortgages and further advances are excluded
Buy to let properties are excluded
Right to buy sales at discounted prices are excluded
Cash sales are not counted as only mortgage data is considered.
Data access: Data free to download from Nationwide website.
Data owner attitude to research use: No view expressed on academic use of data

Category notes: Also homelessness, and physical (property)
Dataset content: New dwellings starts and completion data sourced from Building Control Offices linked to the local councils via Land and Property Services (LPS). Data on homelessness sourced from the Northern Ireland Housing Executive (NIHE). Residential price information derived from HMRC (see entry for Northern Ireland House Price Index). Bulletin contains statistics on starts and completions, homelessness, the Residential Property Price Index and new National House Building Council (NHBC) registered dwellings sales and prices.
Geography notes: Geography does vary according to what dataset is being examined
Time notes: Quarterly publications for the last 2 years are available from the DSD website, previous editions dating back to January - March 2001 are available on request from DSD Analytical Services Unit
Data access:
Free to download from the DSD website
https://www.dsdni.gov.uk/publications/northern-ireland-housing-bulletin-april-june-2015
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Data owner: University of Ulster and Northern Ireland Housing Executive
Source - weblink:
Data available from both the NIHE and the University of Ulster:

http://www.nihe.gov.uk/house_price_index
http://www.rpp.ulster.ac.uk/housing-index.php
Dataset content: Evidence from the market about housing prices (including sales and rental market).  Survey of estate agents, chartered surveyors and property consultants across Northern Ireland in partnership with the Bank of Ireland. Base data for the survey drawn from over 100 companies across Northern Ireland
Data type notes: Trends and spatial patterns in the housing market.  The overall performance of the housing market is measured by a weighted index that reflects the market share of each property type.  Regional analysis considers trends in market areas throughout Northern Ireland. Composite statistics showing average annual prices are also given.
Data access: A summary report of quarterly findings is free to download from University of Ulster and Northern Ireland Housing Executive.

Dataset name: Northern Ireland Residential Property Price Index
Data owner: Northern Ireland Statistics and Research Agency (NISRA)
Dataset content: All property sales in Northern Ireland. Source data obtained from HMRC including: purchase price, property address, date of sale, vendor name, purchaser name, location, property characteristics.
Data quality: Some concerns have been expressed over data quality as some transactions (family transfers etc.) can distort average open market price. But more recent data said to be more credible.
Data access: Data free to download from the NISRA website

Dataset content: This dataset tracks residential property sales in England and Wales submitted to Land Registry for registration.
Time notes:
Data can be downloaded in 3 different formats: 1) single file: contains all the up to date data from 1995 to the current date, 2) monthly file: contains a single monthly file of the transactions received in the period from the first to the last day of the corresponding month, including any changes or deletions to previously downloaded data, 3)
yearly file: contains annual files of up to date data, ranging from 1995 to the current date. Unlike the monthly files described above, yearly files are collated on the date of the transaction/deed date rather than the date that the information was lodged with Land Registry.
Data quality:
There is a time lag between purchase and registration with Land Registry. For most properties, this is completed within 2 months and, as such, the most recent two months worth of data should be treated as provisional. 

Some sales will be omitted where they have not been lodged with Land Registry. Certain types of transactions are not required to be registered with Land Registry. These include: sales that were not for full market value e.g.  the sale of part of a property; transfers, conveyances, assignments or leases at a premium with nominal rent which are:
 - ?Right to buy? sales at a discount, -subject to a lease, - subject to an existing mortgage, -to effect the sale of a share in a property
by way of a gift, - under a compulsory purchase order, under a court order, to Trustees appointed under Deed of appointment. Vesting Deeds Transmissions or Assents of more than one property and leases for seven years or less are also exempt from registration.
Data access: Freely available single file (full time span), monthly and yearly are available via the government webpages. A report builder tool is also provided on their website to tailor datasets by time or location. A attribution should be made.
Data owner attitude to research use: Land Registry request that if you intend to publish from the data that you let them know in advance of publication.
Other notes: Land registry data used to produce DCLG Live tables 576-588  housing statistics

Dataset content: The release presents the mean, median, lower quartile and upper quartile total monthly rent paid, for a number of bedroom/room categories.
Data type notes: This dataset is based on data collected by the Valuation Office Agency to support Local Housing Allowance. Importantly, however, it is emphasised in  publications that the data used to generate these statistics are based on a sample of rental information which is collected by Rent Officers from landlords and letting agents. Because the composition of this sample changes over time, it is not possible to compare median rents provided in this publication with statistics in previous publications to infer trends in the rental market over time
Data quality:
Release notes with a comment on data quality are provided with the annual release. 
The data include all relevant data available and have not been adjusted to produce statistics which are representative of the private rental property market mix in England. However, the underlying data set to these statistics is not drawn from a statistical sample and does not consist of tracked properties. This means that the statistics presented in this release should be considered as indicative only and do not represent accurate measures of the population
Data access: Freely available datasets for 2014, 2013, 2012, 2011. The most recent record is available via the VOA website while additional years are accessed via the National Archive
Data owner attitude to research use: The release notes for these statistics indicate that the VOA have a positive attitude to research use of their data.

Dataset content:
This dataset contains statistics on private sector rent levels in Scotland over the years 2010 to 2015 (years to end-September) using data from the Rent Service Scotland market evidence database. It presents information on rent levels for different property sizes across each of the 18 broad rental market areas in Scotland. It contains information on average rents as well as rents at the higher and lower end of the market.
The rental values in this publication are based on data collected on about 25,000 to 28,000 individual rents each year, representing about 8% to 10% of private rented dwellings.
Geography notes: Data are disaggregated to 18 broad rental market areas
Time notes: Data charts and tables are provided for 2010, 2014 and 2015 within the dataset. Change over time is also given for the period 2010-2015. The previous year's data tables are also available which detail change 2010-2014. It is not clear whether this publication will continue into the future.
Data type notes: Data are obtained from the Rent Service Scotland market evidence database.
Data quality: The data excludes any rents related to social housing, mid-market rents, halls of residence, and private tenancies known to be the subject of housing benefit and regulated tenancies. The market evidence data on private rents is sourced through a variety of means, including private landlord and letting agent returns, mailshot initiatives, as well as advertised rental information. The rental values in this publication are based on data collected on about 25,000 to 28,000 individual rents each year, representing about 8% to 10% of private rented dwellings. It is important to note that the data collected on individual rents may encompass different property types and addresses for each data collection year, and that this publication is not an attempt at providing a case-matched, tracked-sample or weighted-index approach to monitoring changes to rent levels over time. Caution is advised when considering rent levels and trends for property sizes within broad rental market areas which are based on small sample sizes. More detail on data quality issues are provided in the report which accompanies the data tables
Data access: Freely accessible data tables for both 2010-2014 and 2010-2015 are available via the Scottish Government website
Data owner attitude to research use: Research is a use of the data acknowledged in the accompanying report.

Dataset content: Data provided via returns to the Welsh Government from individual private landlords and letting agents via Rent Officers Wales.  Rent Officers Wales is part of the Housing Policy Division of the Welsh Government.   Transactional data only where rent has been paid (therefore excludes cases where housing benefit was the payment).  Data based on simple averages (medians and means)
Data quality: Statistics in this dataset have not been adjusted to produce representative statistics for the private property rental market mix in Wales.
Data access: free to download from the Welsh Government webpage as Excel spreadsheet and PDF report.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Dataset name: Property Transactions in the UK Statistical Release
Dataset content: This dataset contains information on the number and aggregate value of property transactions in England and Wales, Scotland and the UK, broken down by various items
Time notes: Data are updated a monthly, quarterly and annual basis.
Data type notes: Data are taken from the HMRC Stamp Duty and Land Tax Database
Data quality:
Detailed quality reports are provided for all datasets. 

Key issues in terms of coverage include:
- Not all property transactions are captured in the database. 
- Although quite complete issues of  tax avoidance and evasion make it incomplete.
- some records contain limited geographic information so can't  be classified within the published country breakdown.
Data access: A series of freely accessible data tables are provided via the HMRC website. Statistics for 2006-2013 are available via the National Archive.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Category notes: Also covers Finance/Subsidy, benefit information
Dataset content: These rent registration datasets provide information on Housing benefit referrals, pre-tenancy determinations and fair (registered) rent cases.
Time notes: Measures are provided from Q2 1996 until Q1 2011.
Data quality: These data are administrative data and can thus be considered relatively high quality. The aggregated data contained in these tables on Housing Benefit Referrals is considered, however, to be of limited use at the Scotland and Local Authority level, without further dis-aggregation to take account of different property types The data on both Housing Benefit Referrals and Fair(Registered) Rent Cases were also noted to relate to only a minority of tenancies
Data access: A freely accessible time-series dataset from Q2 1996 to Q1 2011 is available via the Scottish Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Social and academic research is an acknowledged use of these statistics according to the 'Use of the data' documentation provided alongside the HSfS releases

Data owner: Scottish Government (Centre for Housing Market Analysis)
Category notes: Could also be classed as Finance
Dataset content: The Scottish housing market bulletin collates a range of statistics on house prices, housing market activity, cost and availability of finance and repossessions.
Geography notes: The majority of figures provided in the publication relate to Scotland as a whole. A few make reference to local authorities
Data quality: The data utilised in this publication are drawn from a range of sources.
Data access: PDFs of each quarterly publication are freely accessible via the Scottish Government website. Statistical datasets are not however provided alongside this release. It is unclear if these could be obtained by request.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Dataset content: The dataset provides information on lettings of social housing in England provided by local authorities and private registered providers (previously known as housing associations) including trends in social housing lettings over time and the characteristics of tenants with new social housing lettings
Time notes: The dataset is published annually but data are recorded continously. Datasets are given from 2011/2012. Within the most recent dataset, England level data are provided from 2004 while only 3 years of LA level data are given.
Data type notes: Data are taken from CORE.
Data quality: CORE is designed to be a complete census of new social housing lettings provided by local authorities and private registered providers that own social housing stock. Therefore no sampling errors should be present in the final dataset. However there will always be a degree of inaccuracy predominately due to non-response and reporting errors by local authorities and private registered providers that submit data and tenants when responding. The number of errors and resulting alterations to raw data is monitored to ensure that quality standards are maintained. Measurement errors are mitigated by ensuring that the questions asked on CORE are defined satisfactorily, are answerable and are fully understood.Data undergo a series of validation checks.
Data access: Freely accessible data tables for 2011/2 onwards are available on the DCLG website. Additional dataset may be available by request.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Dataset name: Social housing sales (including Right to Buy and transfers)
Category notes: Also Management
Dataset content: These data contain information on sales of social housing stock ? whether owned by local authorities or private registered providers. The most common of these sales are by the Right to Buy (and preserved Right to Buy) scheme
Time notes: Measures at the England level are provided from 1980. Those provided for local authorities are slightly summarised with full data only from 1998. Right-to-Buy data is provided quarterly, however, other measures such as social housing sales are provided annually.
Data quality: The LOGASNet figures are audited annually by local authorities and continuously quality assured by DCLG, both of which can result in revisions (see Revisions Policy). The figures are compared against those supplied through the annual LAHS return for consistency, which again can result in revisions. Every effort is made to collect data from every local authority but in occasional instances estimates may be used. Care should be taken using data at a local authority level as the totals are low and therefore can be volatile.
Data access: Freely accessible tables are provided on the DCLG website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Category notes: Could also be classed as Tenure
Dataset content: Information comes from annual returns from social landlords (local authorities and RSLs). Data provides an overview of the number of dwellings, bedsits and bed-spaces owned or partly owned by Welsh social landlords (local authorities and registered social landlords) based on the stock they held as of 31st March that year.
Data type notes: Numeric
Data quality: Technical report available from Welsh Government website on data quality
Data access: Data free to download as an excel spreadsheet or PDF report from welsh Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Dataset name: Social Housing Vacancies, lettings and arrears
Dataset content: Annual returns from local authorities and RSLs. Datasets provides information on number of social housing units rented to tenants, number of social tenants in rent arrears, and number of vacant units. Social housing vacancies by local authority area, duration (eg vacant for 6 months or more), provider, vacancy type (eg sheltered/self contained) and availability.
Data type notes: Numeric
Data quality: Technical information available from the Welsh Government webpage
Data access: Free to download as an Excel spreadsheet/PDF report from Welsh Government webpage
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of data use for research

Dataset name: Housing for Older People, those with Disabilities and those with Supported Tenancies (Housing Statistics for Scotland)
Dataset content:
This dataset contains information on housing for older people, those with disabilities and those with supported tenancies. 
This includes 
- Local authority stock
- Housing association stock 
- Scottish Homes stock
- All stock 
- Scotland level summary
- Provision by local authority area for chosen agency and year
Time notes:
Different figures within the dataset are provided for different timescales. 
- Local authority stock - time series table from 2001 to 2015 
- Housing association stock - time series table from 2001 to 2013
- Scottish Homes stock - time series table from 2001 to 2005 
- All stock - time series table from 1996 to 2013
 - Scotland level summary from 2001 to 2013 
- Provision by local authority area for chosen agency and year (1996-2015)
Data type notes: These data are drawn from RSL and local authority administrative data. Data is collected from local authorities by the Scottish Government and from RSLs by the Scottish Housing Regulator.
Data quality: These are government administrative statistics so offer full coverage. It is noted however that there may be some inconsistency in the way that supported housing is categorised by different local authorities and where local authorities are unable to classify their properties into the categories asked for, they may estimate these figures. A more detailed Data Quality report is provided with alongside all HSfS statistical releases
Data access: A full freely accessible data table is provided via the Scottish Government website.
Data owner attitude to research use: Social and academic research is an acknowledged use of these statistics according to the 'Use of the data' documentation provided alongside the HSfS releases

Dataset name: Opinions and Lifestyle Survey: Fulfilling Potential outcomes and indicators
Data owner: DWP and Office for Disability Issues
Dataset content: This dataset contains information taken from the Opinions and Lifestyle Survey which is relevant to the Fulfilling Potential strategy which encourages closer working to empower disabled people to achieve their full potential. Dataset content: Bank Stats (Monetary and Financial) which includes statistics on lending, approvals and repayments and statistics published by ONS - although no further details is given. The stock of housing equity is the amount of wealth tied up in housing which does not have any loans secured on it. Housing Equity Withdrawal (HEW) is defined as the 'balance of effects' on the stock of housing equity from: Changes in the stock of secured lending when households take out loans or repay debt; Changes in the stock of housing wealth, e.g. when new properties are built or improvements are made to existing properties. HEW is the net effect of the different ways in which individual households might inject or withdraw housing equity.

Dataset content:
Data, updated every 6 months, on membership numbers of competent person schemes and the number of building jobs they have carried out.  

1.Registered membership is by business, not by individual. Many businesses will consist of more than one competent individual so the total number of competent individuals will be higher than the registered membership figures.
2.Schemes are authorised by the type of work that their registered members carry out. However, in many schemes, particularly those dealing with the installation of heating, hot water service, air-conditioning, mechanical ventilation and plumbing systems, registered members do more than one type of work. To prevent as far as possible double counting of registered members or notifications to local authorities (which often encompass more than one type of work) the statistics combine all types of work (except electrical installations) for each of the scheme operators.
3.Schemes have changed since the data first started being collected, so it is not always possible to make meaningful comparisons between past and current data.
Time notes: Data are updated on a 6 monthly basis. Data are broken down to competent person schemes

Category notes: Also Physical (property), Homelessness, Finance and lending, Tenure, Subsidy and Benefits
Dataset content:
Data drawn from a number of sources to given an overview of housing statistics in Northern Ireland.  Lists of all sources are supplied in appendices accessible at the DSD webpage. A compendium of housing statistics for Northern Ireland.  There are 6 main sections of data which cover: 
- Housing supply -  stock, residential planning, social and private sector starts and completions, tenure, and volume of output by construction sector  
- Energy -  central heaing by fuel type, SAP ratings, Warm Homes Scheme and Boiler Replacement Scheme 
- Social renting demand - NIHE rents, HA rents, homelessness, social sector waiting lists and applications, NIHE tenants on HB 
- Private renting demand - length of residence, median rent, number of households in private rented by region/country
- Owner occupier demand -  Residential Property Price Index (RPPI), NHBC new dwelling sales and prices, co-ownership, lending and affordability, mortgage cases and orders
- household characteristics - household projections, household type, household income, rates
Geography notes: Geography does vary according to what dataset is being examined
Time notes: Publications for the latest 3 financial years are available on the DSD website, previous editions of the publication back to 1999-00 are available on request from DSD Analytical Services Unit
Data quality: Data quality information is included in each of the appendices 1:6 for the datasets
Data access: Data free to download from DSD website in word, excel and PDF formats.
Data owner attitude to research use: Appears supportive of using data for research

Dataset name: Quarterly revenue outturn for local authorities
Dataset content: This dataset contains administrative data on quarterly revenue outturn for local authorities in England.
Data quality: These are government administrative data so can be considered high quality. The offer full coverage of local authorities in England. A report detailing the strengths and limitations of the data together with a comment on data quality is provided with the statistical release.
Data access: Freely accessible quarterly datasets are provided for 2011-present via the DCLG website. It is unclear whether earlier datasets could be obtained by request.
Data owner attitude to research use: Government attitudes to research use of their data appear favourable.

Category notes: Includes people, place, and services
Dataset content: Range of datasets have been used to construct the index including data on income, employment, health, education, access to services, community safety, physical environment and housing. The official measure of relative deprivation for small areas in Wales where separate measurements (eg data for income, housing and health) are combined into a single number. It is designed to identify small areas with the highest concentration of several different types of deprivation. WIMD is a measure of multiple deprivation that is both an area-based measure and a measure of relative deprivation.
Time notes: Data is available on the site for the years: 2000, 2004, 2005, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2014
Data quality: Technical report on data quality available from the Welsh Government website.
Data access: Appears supportive of data use for research.
